title: Jeffersonian architecture
text:
Jeffersonian architecture is an American form of <a href="Neoclassical%20architecture">Neo-Classicism</a> and/or <a href="Neo-Palladianism">Neo-Palladianism</a> embodied in the architectural designs of <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. President</a> and <a href="polymath">polymath</a> <a href="Thomas%20Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a>, after whom it is named. These include his home (<a href="Monticello">Monticello</a>), his retreat (<a href="Poplar%20Forest">Poplar Forest</a>),the university he founded (<a href="University%20of%20Virginia">University of Virginia</a>), and his designs for the homes of friends and political allies (notably <a href="Barboursville%20%28James%20Barbour%29">Barboursville</a>). Over a dozen private homes bearing his personal stamp still stand today. Jefferson's style was popular in the early American period at about the same time that the more mainstream <a href="Greek%20Revival%20architecture">Greek Revival architecture</a> was also coming into vogue (1790s–1830s) with his assistance.
Sources and inspiration.
In colonial Virginia during the 18th century there were no schools of architecture, so Jefferson learned the trade on his own from various books and by studying some of the various classical architectural designs of the day. As a self-taught architect and <a href="classicist">classicist</a>, he was most heavily influenced by the Italian revivalist architect <a href="Andrea%20Palladio">Andrea Palladio</a> (1508–1580). His "bible" was <a href="Andrea%20Palladio">Andrea Palladio</a>'s "The Four Books of Architecture", which taught him the basic principles of classical design. Jeffersonian architecture is therefore perhaps best described as "<a href="Palladian">Palladian</a>" in inspiration.
Jefferson was also influenced by architect <a href="James%20Gibbs">James Gibbs</a> (1682–1754), and by French Neo-classical buildings, such as the <a href="H%C3%B4tel%20de%20Salm">Hôtel de Salm</a> in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, when he served as <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20France">Ambassador to France</a>. While the Jeffersonian style incorporates Palladian proportions and themes, it is at the same time unique to Jefferson's own personal sensibility and the materials available to him in early republican Virginia.
Throughout his adult life Jefferson made many architectural drawings and wrote extensively about architectural design. Today there are over 600 pages of architectural documents by Jefferson now housed at the <a href="Massachusetts%20Historical%20Society">Massachusetts Historical Society</a> and are commonly referred to as the <a href="Coolidge%20Collection">Coolidge Collection</a>.
Characteristics.
One characteristic which typifies Jefferson's architecture is the use of the octagon and octagonal forms in his designs. Palladio never used octagons, but Jefferson employed them as a design motif—halving them, elongating them, and employing them in whole as with the dome of Monticello, or the entire house at Poplar Forest.
Monticello.
Located just outside <a href="Charlottesville%2C%20Virginia">Charlottesville</a>, Jefferson's <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a> home and estate is situated on the summit of an -high peak in the <a href="Southwest%20Mountains">Southwest Mountains</a>. Its name comes from the <a href="Italian%20language">Italian</a> for "little mountain." Jefferson began work on his original “Monticello” in 1768. He left his home in 1784 to serve as Minister of the United States to France. During his tenure in Europe, he had an opportunity to see some of the classical buildings with which he had become acquainted from his reading, as well as to discover the "modern" trends in French architecture that were then fashionable in Paris. His decision to remodel his own home may date from this period. In 1794, following his service as the first U.S. Secretary of State (1790–93), Jefferson began rebuilding his <a href="manor%20house">manor house</a> based on the ideas he had acquired in Europe. The remodeling continued throughout most of his presidency (1801–09).
Jefferson added a center hallway and a parallel set of rooms to the structure, more than doubling its area. He removed the second full-height story from the original house and replaced it with a <a href="Mezzanine%20%28architecture%29">mezzanine</a> bedroom floor. The most dramatic element of the new design was an octagonal <a href="dome">dome</a>, which he placed above the West front of the building in place of a second-story portico. The room inside the dome was described by a visitor as "a noble and beautiful apartment," but it was rarely used—perhaps because it was hot in summer and cold in winter, or because it could only be reached by climbing a steep and very narrow flight of stairs. The dome room has now been restored to its appearance during Jefferson's lifetime, with "Mars <a href="yellow">yellow</a>" walls and a painted green floor, although safety regulations about use of the narrow stairs to the upper floors largely preclude visitors to Monticello from seeing the room.
Monticello, along with the nearby University of Virginia, was designated a <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Site</a> in 1987.
Influence.
In 1803, President Jefferson appointed <a href="Benjamin%20Henry%20Latrobe">Benjamin Henry Latrobe</a> as surveyor of public buildings in the United States, thus introducing <a href="Greek%20Revival%20architecture">Greek Revival architecture</a> to the country for the first time. Latrobe went on to design a number of important public buildings in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> and <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, including work on the <a href="United%20States%20Capitol">United States Capitol</a> and the <a href="Bank%20of%20Pennsylvania">Bank of Pennsylvania</a>.
Even after Jefferson's style went out of vogue for other public buildings, it continued to have an influence on many <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a> church designs on the <a href="East%20Coast%20of%20the%20United%20States">East Coast</a> through the mid-20th century. The style is still employed on some <a href="American%20South">Southern</a> college campuses, particularly in Virginia and the <a href="Peabody%20College">Peabody College</a> campus of <a href="Vanderbilt%20University">Vanderbilt University</a>, and it has enjoyed a certain re-emergence among some newer 21st century <a href="evangelical">evangelical</a> church complexes.
The <a href="University%20of%20Mary%20Washington">University of Mary Washington</a>, previously the University of Virginia's college for women, is another primary example of Jefferson's architecture.
An example of Jeffersonian architecture outside the United States can be found in one of China's top universities, <a href="Tsinghua%20University">Tsinghua University</a> in <a href="Beijing">Beijing</a>. The University's "Grand Auditorium" was designed with elements from the Jeffersonian architectural style in the early 20th century.
